Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: This morning, I woke up to the sound of my spouse bustling around the kitchen, already stressed about the relatives arriving in a few hours. “Can you please vacuum and tidy the living room before you go?” they asked, eyes pleading. I nodded, feeling the weight of making sure everything was perfect for our guests. But I also had to vote today—something I promised myself I wouldn’t skip, no matter how busy things got. At the polling station, after waiting in line, the poll worker handed my ballot back. “Sorry, the envelope is smudged. Please re-sign it so your vote counts.” I glanced at the clock, anxiety rising. My spouse was counting on me to help at home, and I knew they’d be frustrated if I was late. But the poll worker’s tone was firm; I couldn’t just rush through this. Torn between my duty as a spouse and my responsibility as a voter, I felt my chest tighten, caught in the middle of two worlds that both demanded my full attention.
